moves.1. e4:
A Long Road To Nowhere

This opponent and I have a long running battle. I always feel I have a chance against him, but it never quite works the way its planned.
Time to start the brave and ambitious stuff ;-)
moves.10. Qd3 Bc5 11. Nc3 e4 12. Qg3 O-O: I chose to do that first to prevent Qxg7 losing the knight at f6.
moves.13. Kd1: Which loses me the rook unfortunately but hey ho.
moves.13... Qg4+ 14. Qxg4 Nxg4: Lets try that on this side.....
moves.15. Nh3 Rad8 16. b4 Bb6 17. Bb2 f5 18. N: Just wandering about now, poking and seeing what happens. I'm not a great planner as you can tell.
moves.37... Rd5d6 38. Rxd6+ Rxd6 39. bxa6 Rxa6: Thats definately an error, doesn't look like it now, but later on I NEEDED that rook.
moves.43. Rxa1 Bxa1 44. Nf4+ Kf6 45. Nd5+: I was banking on that extra pawn.
moves.45... Ke5 46. Nb4 f4: And of course go and hand it straight back.
moves.47. Nc6+ Kf5 48. Nxa7 fxg3 49. fxg3 Be5: Got it again, but now his knight is in play rather than chasing down an errant awn on the other side of the board. If he grabs my pawn it doesn't matter whether he loses the knight, a forced mate is out (there is an unforced mate, but this opponent is waaaayyyyy to competitive to co-operate)
moves.51. Nd4+ Kf4 52. Ne2+ Kf3 53. Nd4+ Kg2 5: Cue the dance of the five pieces.....
moves.56... Kg2 57. Ke4 Kh3 58. Kf4 Be1 59. Ke: A mistake there giving him the opportunity of K-e3 forcing the draw.
Another mistake but I didn't think it mattered, he had the pawn.
moves.72. Nf3+ Kh1 73. Kxf2: I'm left with a forced move which sacs my queen *cries*
moves.73... g1=Q+ 74. Nxg1: I'm sure a better player would have found a way, but pleased just to get a draw.
